title: A Less Invasive Strategy for Ruptured Cerebral Aneurysms with Intracerebral Hematomas: Endovascular Coil Embolization Followed by Stereotactic Aspiration of Hematomas Using Urokinase
patient: A 39-year-old female patient presented to our hospital in a deep stupor mental status of two hours duration. Her clinical status was compatible with WFNS grade-V (GCS E1/V1/M4). According to her family, she did not have any significant past medical history. Her brain CT scan revealed a diffuse IVH, and a large ICH in the left prefrontal area with an estimated volume of 56 mL (). Her brain CTA and DSA revealed a 12 mm ruptured right-IC-Ophthalmic aneurysm (). She underwent endovascular coil embolization using 7 coils (: preoperative, : postoperative), which was followed by SRH and EVD (: postoperative). Seven days later, a brain CT scan revealed a significant decrease in ICH and IVH (: postoperative 7 days). She was transferred to a rehabilitation center. At 6-months postoperatively, the patient still showed a stupor mental state, which was compatible with a GOS of 2 (persistent vegetative state).
